title: Wye Valley Canoe & Climb
tagline: Paddle the Wye, scale the cliffs, explore ancient ruins in one of Britain's most beautiful river valleys
suitableFor: Active friends or couples who enjoy outdoor adventures and are comfortable with some physical exertion. Some prior experience with canoeing or climbing is helpful but not essential.
notSuitableFor: Those with significant mobility issues, fear of heights, or who prefer purely relaxing, non-physical holidays.

stops.title: River Wye Canoeing
stops.description: Paddle through the stunning Wye Valley AONB, drifting past ancient woodland, limestone cliffs, and wildlife. Half-day trips typically run from Symonds Yat to Monmouth (7 miles) or shorter options available. All equipment provided including canoe, paddles, buoyancy aids. No experience needed - guides give full instruction.
stops.travelToNext: On the water to Ye Olde Ferrie Inn
stops.insiderTip: Watch for kingfishers flashing electric blue along the banks. Keep quiet and you might see herons and cormorants. The section below Symonds Yat has some minor rapids - exciting but not scary!

wetAlt.title: Puzzlewood Film Set
wetAlt.description: Mystical ancient woodland used in Star Wars, Doctor Who, and many other films. Atmospheric in any weather - arguably better in mist! Entry £8-10.

budgetAlt.title: Wye Valley Walk Section
budgetAlt.description: Walk the stunning Wye Valley Walk from Symonds Yat Rock to Monmouth (7 miles). Free apart from parking. Get the bus back.

stops.title: Ye Olde Ferrie Inn
stops.description: Historic riverside pub at Symonds Yat East, accessible by the hand-pulled rope ferry (one of only a handful in Britain). Famous for good pub food, real ales, and spectacular setting. Outdoor seating by the river.
stops.ferryInfo: Hand-pulled rope ferry operates dawn-dusk, 80p donation
stops.insiderTip: Take the rope ferry across - it's a unique experience and the ferryman has worked the crossing for decades. Book a table on the terrace for river views.

alternative.title: The Saracens Head Inn (Symonds Yat East)
alternative.description: Another riverside pub with its own ferry. Good food and accommodation.

budgetAlt.title: Picnic at Symonds Yat Rock
budgetAlt.description: Pick up supplies and picnic at the famous viewpoint 500ft above the Wye. Peregrine falcons nest on the cliffs.

stops.title: Symonds Yat Rock Viewpoint
stops.description: Climb the 500ft to Symonds Yat Rock for one of the finest viewpoints in Britain. The River Wye loops dramatically below, and peregrine falcons often soar at eye level. RSPB volunteers often on site with telescopes (April-August).
stops.insiderTip: Evening light is magical here. The peregrines returned to nest in 1982 after decades of absence - now they're a regular sight. The cafe at the top serves good cakes.

wetAlt.title: Dean Heritage Centre
wetAlt.description: Museum exploring the Forest of Dean's mining and industrial heritage. Indoor exhibitions plus outdoor trails through woodland. Good for families.

stops.title: The Anchor Inn (Tintern)
stops.description: Charming riverside pub with rooms right next to Tintern Abbey. Traditional decor, cosy bar with real ales, and excellent restaurant using local produce. Perfect base for abbey exploration.
stops.insiderTip: Room 3 has views of the abbey ruins - magical when lit up at night. Book dinner in the restaurant - the steaks are excellent.

budgetAlt.title: St Briavels Castle YHA
budgetAlt.description: Sleep in a 13th-century castle! Atmospheric hostel with medieval banquet hall. Basic but unforgettable. 15min drive from Tintern.

campingAlt.title: Wye Valley Camping (Whitebrook)
campingAlt.description: Small, peaceful campsite in the valley. Basic facilities but beautiful setting.

stops.title: Rock Climbing Introduction
stops.description: Guided rock climbing session on the limestone crags near Symonds Yat or Wintour's Leap. Suitable for complete beginners - all equipment provided and expert instruction. Learn to climb, belay, and abseil on real rock in a stunning setting.
stops.insiderTip: Ask for Wintour's Leap if you want drama - it's a 200ft limestone cliff overlooking the Wye. Symonds Yat crags are more beginner-friendly with varied routes.

wetAlt.title: Go Ape (Forest of Dean)
wetAlt.description: High ropes adventure through the trees at this popular treetop course. Book in advance.

budgetAlt.title: Wye Valley Walk to The Buckstone
budgetAlt.description: Hike from Staunton to The Buckstone - a famous rocking stone with panoramic views. 4-mile circular walk, free.

stops.title: Tintern Abbey
stops.description: Explore the romantic ruins of this magnificent 12th-century Cistercian abbey. Wordsworth wrote about it, Turner painted it - the Gothic arches against the sky are unforgettable. Allow 1-2 hours to explore fully.
stops.insiderTip: Late afternoon light through the ruined windows is magical for photos. The audio guide (included) tells fascinating stories of monastic life. Combined ticket with Raglan Castle available.

wetAlt.title: Abbey still good!
wetAlt.description: Ruins are atmospheric in any weather - arguably more romantic in mist or light rain. Bring waterproofs and embrace it.

stops.title: The Moon and Sixpence (Tintern)
stops.description: Excellent cafe/restaurant opposite Tintern Abbey. Local produce, homemade cakes, and good coffee. Vegetarian-friendly. Perfect post-abbey refuel.

alternative.title: The Wild Hare (Tintern)
alternative.description: Casual eatery with wood-fired pizzas and local beers. Outdoor seating.

budgetAlt.title: Abbey Mill Tea Room
budgetAlt.description: Simple cafe with outdoor seating by the river. Good for a quick sandwich.

standard.notes: Based on 2 adults, pub B&B, 2 activities

budget.notes: Hostel/camping, one paid activity, packed lunches

premium.notes: Boutique B&B, all activities, restaurant meals

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: The Wye Valley has a mild, sheltered climate but expect some rain (it is Wales!). Canoeing runs in most conditions except heavy floods. Rock climbing may be cancelled in heavy rain as wet rock is slippery.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: Weekend traffic on the A466 along the Wye Valley can be heavy, especially on sunny days. Parking at Symonds Yat Rock fills early. Consider arriving early or using the main car park and walking up.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: Canoe hire and climbing sessions should be booked in advance, especially for weekends. Tintern Abbey doesn't require advance booking but online tickets are slightly cheaper.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: This itinerary requires moderate fitness. Canoeing is suitable for beginners. Rock climbing requires some upper body strength but guides adapt to ability. Walking to viewpoints involves some hills.
knowBeforeYouGo.flooding: The Wye can flood after heavy rain. Operators will contact you if sessions are cancelled. In these conditions, the wild valley looks dramatic - bring waterproofs and enjoy the walks instead.
knowBeforeYouGo.border: The Wye Valley straddles the England-Wales border. Symonds Yat is in England (Herefordshire), Tintern is in Wales (Monmouthshire). Phone signal is patchy throughout.

addDay.title: Add Caving Adventure
addDay.description: Explore underground cave systems in the Forest of Dean with Adventure Wye. Squeeze through passages, see formations, and experience total darkness.

alternative.title: Forest of Dean MTB
alternative.description: Swap climbing for mountain biking at the Pedalabikeaway trails in the Forest of Dean. Blue, red, and black graded trails plus skills area.
